page.title: 05Grafham Area, Forestry.
page.content: The{woodland}in this area was planted by the{Forestry Commision}in the 1930's on poor arable or scrubland and is managed by the Anglian Water Authority. Sycamore, oak and ash trees were planted on approximately 50 hectares. The ash trees did not survive. Many elms were planted in the 1960's but have succombed to disease and died. A number of Scots Pines have been planted. They grow well and are a valuable asset at maturity, as are the oaks. There exists a crop of Norway Spruce which are felled after two or three years and are sold as Christmas trees. The planting programme is subject to financial cuts by local government so the number of trees planted each year is not constant.
